Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Windloading overnight had obscured much of bootpack. Continued moderate loading on Southerlys. Over structure on polar aspects near treeline is good with the LOC down 90-120cm and no notable instability in the overlying slab. Second CT produced no fracture of LOC.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpack damp throughout

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
We skied slope;
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: I traveled on NE and E aspects BTL from 8,800' to10,100', and found an average snow depth of 100-120cm. The Xmas Eve ice crust was 1-3mm and buried under 2cm of new snow from the past 24 hours. The crust is widespread from the parking area to the top of the gem. Skies were obscured by a mix of low clouds and fog, and temperatures at the parking area were a balmy 25F at 9:30am and 29F at noon. I experienced no cracking or collapsing throughout the tour.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Revisited a previous remotely triggered avalanche from Dec 4, 2022 failing on the Dec 1 facet layer. Where avalanche occurred about ~ 60-70cm less snow than adjacent area. A moderate to strong AR storm is expected early next week with significant liquid precipitation. No weakness found on the Dec 1 PWL with snowpack tests in this area.

Collapsing, localized; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Experienced collapse nearby but did not extend to dig site. Did not identify individual mid-pack layers 65-95cm but none presented as concerning and spent little time on grain ID besides layer of concern.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile dug 7 days post incident: 100' wide, slope angle 33-37, aspect 270-285. Avalanche failed on both 12/8 (48-49cm) and 11/27 (24-27cm) faceted layers. Stability tests: ECTX x 2, but both tests failed @27cm and propagated with heavy force (kicking shovel). There was very little untracked snow to perform tests, and the column sites were too close to the crown (<1m) to yield valuable results.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This pit was dug on an similar slope to an adjacent avalanche accident.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This pit was ~10 meters above a shot hole from previous week. A quick pit about 4 meters away from the shot hole yielded similar results on the same layer. That lower pit was one meter deep instead of 80 cm and it had a firmer slab above a thicker layer of facets. ECTP17 and PST 25/100 End down 75 cm from surface.
Wind had loaded this zone and then stripped the surface snow away.
Another group on skin track reported an ECTP18 40 cm down from surface (HS 90cm)
New snow failed at the old snow interface on a thin layer of facet grains

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Wide open trees, wind affected

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: West facing and solars aspects stayed dry till just about 330 or 4pm. Still good skiing on solars. Temperatures show a healing snowpack and test results verify in this location. One collapse lower in the flats on a shaded aspect earlier in the morning. Melting surface hoar and NSF mixed with broken PP on surface. Clear skies and cold temps previous night.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Cracking;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Gryfja tekin í Kúahjalla ofan við Neskaupstað. Mjög kalt í veðri en stillt. Enginn vindur í morgunsárið. Snjór nær almennt til sjávar en þúfur og grasbalar standa enn uppúr í fjalli. Snjór er nokkuð þéttur, þurr og vel bundinn. Um er að ræða tvö lög. Örlítill munur er á þéttleika efsta lags miðað við neðra, en við skóflupróf kom stundum brot milli þessara laga.
Hef litlar áhyggjur af snjólögum eins og staðan er í dag.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 3mm SH down 40cm. Faceted mid/lower snowpack. 3mm DH on ground. No results on ECT

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug in the center of the West AJ test slope. Found a very loose weak layer below a very dense firm slab. After multiple tests failing on isolation, Otis chased a snowball down the hill and triggered a large collapse felt and heard throughout the entire slope. Good potential for a deep persistent weak layer, who knows how much load it will hold before it fails?

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Obs: JW, LW Site: BTL clearing, sheltered, solar

Pit dug near shooting cracks that ran from the Hourglass deep persistent slab avalanche that occurred naturally sometime on Sunday Dec 11. Avalanche occurred on a NE aspect with shooting cracks than ran up to 1000' into N/NW terrain.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, widespread; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Collapsing, widespread; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug downhill of the cross towards the tram. Multiple collapses underfoot while we toured up the main hiking trail. Snow surface looser and softer than expected after yesterday's strong storm winds. Snowfall must have continued after the wind died last night.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Wind-packed snow on surface from previous SW winds. Test failures tended to be irregular, stepping down to base of weak layer from 42 to 19. 1st ECT broke at ground but column narrower at base so topheavy.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: ECTP30 PST 65/100 ARR
Guide training and data gathering day with Alex Weston. Column test failures were on 2-3mm rounding facets below the lower of two decomposing crust layers.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpack seemed to be settling, this area did not seem to be very affected by the cross-loaded winds we saw skinning over on the northeast shoulder, it is important to note the terrain above where we dug the pit is steep and consistently sheds on top of this area, which we did see in some areas while traversing over to where our pit was dug.
